definition: Free China (Cold War era term for the Republic of China on Taiwan, as distinct from "Red China")

country/nation/state/national/CL:個|个[ge4]
Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Kaohsiung Incident (aka Formosa Incident), a crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, on 10 December 1979 during Taiwan's martial law period
Lee Teng-hui (1923-2020), Taiwanese politician, president of ROC 1988-2000
Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer
anti-communist

Zhou Zuoren (1885-1967), brother of Lu Xun 魯迅|鲁迅, academic in Japanese and Greek studies, briefly imprisoned after the war as Japanese collaborator, persecuted and died of unknown causes during the Cultural Revolution
editorial (in a newspaper)/CL:篇[pian1]
Guomindang or Kuomintang (KMT)/Nationalist Party
Zou Taofen (1895-1944), journalist, political theorist and publisher
Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), co-founder of the Chinese Communist Party in 1921
China Times (newspaper)
Chen Shui-Bian (1950-), Taiwanese DPP 民進黨|民进党 politician, president of the Republic of China 2000-2008
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Dagong Bao, popular newspaper name/Ta Kung Pao, newspaper founded 1902 in Beijing, now published in Hong Kong
Liang Shuming (1893-1988), modern philosopher and teacher in the neo-Confucian tradition
Chiang Kai-shek (1887-1975), military leader, head of the Nationalist government in China 1928-1949 and the government in exile on Taiwan 1950-1975
